creator: micromet
title: Waterproofing a Capacitance Soil Moisture Sensor
materials_required: Adhesive-lined Polyolefin Heat-shrink tubing in three sizes: 1/4", 1/2" and 3/4" diam. with at least 3:1 shrink
description: This project describes how to waterproof a capacitive soil moisture sensor using adhesive-lined heat shrink and other common tools. This makes the sensor more useful for monitoring soil water status in various environments like potted plants, gardens, or greenhouses.
steps: Test the capacitance-based soil moisture sensor with an Arduino to ensure it's functioning correctly before waterproofing.
Remove the connector from the sensor using a flush cutter, exposing the solder through-holes.
Prepare the signal wire and solder it to the sensor, trimming any excess wire and cleaning the solder joint.
Apply lacquer or nail polish to the exposed circuits on the front and back of the sensor, allowing it to dry in a well-ventilated area.
File the corners of the PCB sensor with sandpaper or a file to prevent them from piercing the heat shrink tubing.
Cut three sections of heat shrink tubing: 1/4" diam. - 1.25 inches long, 1/2" diam. - 0.75 inches long, and 3/4" diam. = 1.5 to 1.75 inches long.
Apply the 1/4" diameter tubing with the heat gun, being careful with the heat.
Add the 1/2" diameter heat-shrink tubing using the heat gun.
Apply the 3/4" diameter tubing, ensuring the adhesive melts and seals all joints. Apply pressure to the heat shrink while it's still warm to improve the seal.
Apply a thin layer of nail polish at the sensor/tubing seam for extra waterproofing protection.
Test the probes again with an Arduino or other microcontroller, submerging the sensors in water to verify performance.
